subject: Sleep
title: PTSD Nightmares
description: A short lesson to help you apply PTSD Nightmares.

hook.text: A combat veteran relives the same explosion every night for years. The trauma replays like a broken record.

buildup.text: Up to 90 percent of PTSD patients experience chronic nightmares, far more than any other sleep disorder.

discovery.text: Normally, REM sleep strips emotional charge from memories. In PTSD, the amygdala stays hyperactive during REM.

twist.text: Instead of processing the trauma, REM sleep re-traumatizes the brain each night, maintaining the disorder.

climax.text: The blood pressure drug prazosin blocks noradrenaline in the brain and reduces PTSD nightmares significantly.

punchline.text: In PTSD, the brain's dream repair shop is broken.

quiz.question: Why do PTSD nightmares persist?
options: The person chooses to replay traumatic memories
The amygdala stays hyperactive during REM, preventing emotional processing
REM sleep is absent in PTSD
